questions.text: A 42-year-old male had visited Mumbai a few months back. He had a history of bloody diarrhea for a few days on returning, which subsided on its own. options.text: The life cycle is partly in sheep and partly in man

options.label: C
options.text: The treatment of choice is metronidazole

options.label: D
options.text: The aspirate shows “sterile pus” on microscopy

questions.correct_answer: B. The life cycle is partly in sheep and partly in man
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The life cycle is partly in sheep and partly in man.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Entamoeba histolytica is the causative agent of amebic liver abscess, with a life cycle that occurs exclusively in humans, not sheep. The treatment includes metronidazole, often combined with other agents like chloroquine and diloxanide furoate, and the condition is characterized by "sterile pus" in the liver abscess aspirate.
  • ➤ Entamoeba histolytica is the causative agent of amebic liver abscess, with a life cycle that occurs exclusively in humans, not sheep.
  • ➤ The treatment includes metronidazole, often combined with other agents like chloroquine and diloxanide furoate, and the condition is characterized by "sterile pus" in the liver abscess aspirate.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with a known history of diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, deep rapid breathing, and a fruity odor on his breath.   • ➤ Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) is identified by high blood glucose, low serum bicarbonate, low arterial pH, elevated anion gap, and significant ketonemia.
  • ➤ It often presents with symptoms such as abdominal pain, deep rapid breathing (Kussmaul respirations), and a fruity odor on the breath.

questions.text: A clinician administers an intravenous drug to a patient at 8 AM with an initial plasma concentration of 200 mg/L. The drug has a half-life of 4 hours and follows first-order kinetics. What will be the plasma concentration of the drug at 8 PM on the same day?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Given:
  • • Initial concentration (C₀) : 200 mg/L Half-life (t½) : 4 hours Duration from 8 AM to 8 PM : 12 hours
  • • Initial concentration (C₀) : 200 mg/L
  • • Initial concentration (C₀)
  • • Half-life (t½) : 4 hours
  • • Half-life (t½)
  • • Duration from 8 AM to 8 PM : 12 hours
  • • Duration from 8 AM to 8 PM
  • • To calculate the plasma concentration at 8 PM after 12 hours, we use the property of half-lives in first-order kinetics, where the drug concentration decreases by half with each half-life. Here's the calculation:
  • • After 1 half-life (4 hours, 12 PM) : 200 /2=100 mg/L After 2 half-lives (8 hours, 4 PM) : 100 /2=50 mg/L After 3 half-lives (12 hours, 8 PM) : 50/2=25 mg/L
  • • After 1 half-life (4 hours, 12 PM) : 200 /2=100 mg/L
  • • After 1 half-life (4 hours, 12 PM)
  • • After 2 half-lives (8 hours, 4 PM) : 100 /2=50 mg/L
  • • After 2 half-lives (8 hours, 4 PM)
  • • After 3 half-lives (12 hours, 8 PM) : 50/2=25 mg/L
  • • After 3 half-lives (12 hours, 8 PM)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The drug follows first-order kinetics where the rate of drug elimination is proportional to the drug concentration in the plasma; here the drug concentration decreases by half with each half-life.
  • ➤ The drug follows first-order kinetics where the rate of drug elimination is proportional to the drug concentration in the plasma; here the drug concentration decreases by half with each half-life.

options.text: Drug B is more potent than Drug A.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drug B acts as a competitive antagonist, shifting the dose-response curve rightward without affecting the maximum efficacy, while Drug C, showing reduced efficacy and no shift in potency, is a non-competitive antagonist. Remember the rule: leftward and upward shifts in dose-response curves suggest increased potency and efficacy, respectively.
  • ➤ Drug B acts as a competitive antagonist, shifting the dose-response curve rightward without affecting the maximum efficacy, while Drug C, showing reduced efficacy and no shift in potency, is a non-competitive antagonist.

questions.text: A patient presents with spirometry results showing an FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7 after salbutamol nebulization and an FEV1 of 44% of the predicted value. According to the GOLD criteria, how should this patient's COPD be classified?

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with swollen knee joints and non-blanching rashes on his legs as seen in the picture. Urine examination reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with pain in his right ear. On examination, there is no visible infection or trauma. The patient mentions that the pain sometimes radiates to his jaw and neck. Which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for the pain in the ear?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Auriculotemporal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), is responsible for supplying sensation to the anterior and superior parts of the auricle and the external acoustic meatus, and can cause referred pain to the ear from the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a chronic cough and recurrent respiratory infections undergoes a CT scan of the chest to evaluate for bronchiectasis. Which of the following CT findings is least likely to be associated with bronchiectasis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crazy paving appearance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The crazy paving pattern on CT is not typically associated with bronchiectasis. It suggests other lung pathologies like pulmonary alveolar proteinosis or acute interstitial pneumonia. Classic CT findings in bronchiectasis include the tree in bud appearance and the signet ring appearance. Traction bronchiectasis can occur in the context of lung fibrosis.
  • ➤ The crazy paving pattern on CT is not typically associated with bronchiectasis.

  • ➤ Classic CT findings in bronchiectasis include the tree in bud appearance and the signet ring appearance.
  • ➤ Traction bronchiectasis can occur in the context of lung fibrosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man was rushed to the emergency department after a severe crush injury to his leg sustained in a workplace accident. He has significant muscle damage and laboratory tests reveal a serum potassium (K+) level of 5.5 mEq/L. Which of the following changes is most likely to occur to the resting membrane potential in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse. After fitting her with a pessary, what is the first step to check if the pessary is adequately retained?

options.label: A
options.text: Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place

options.label: B
options.text: Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained

options.label: C
options.text: Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary

options.label: D
options.text: Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place

questions.correct_answer: A. Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first step to check if a pessary is adequately retained after fitting is to ask the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver. This maneuver increases intra-abdominal pressure, which helps determine if the pessary remains in place under stress conditions.
  • ➤ The first step to check if a pessary is adequately retained after fitting is to ask the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver.
  • ➤ This maneuver increases intra-abdominal pressure, which helps determine if the pessary remains in place under stress conditions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a history of chronic alcohol use. He has abstained from alcohol for three days and is now experiencing irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. His vital signs are notable for tachycardia and hypertension. On physical examination, he is tremulous and diaphoretic. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alcohol Withdrawal Delirium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delirium Tremens (DTs) (alcohol withdrawal delirium) is a medical emergency and if untreated the mortality rate is around 20%. The symptoms and signs include disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucination (most commonly visual), coarse tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity. It usually occurs after 48-72 hours of the last alcohol intake or reduction in the amount of alcohol use.
  • ➤ Delirium Tremens (DTs) (alcohol withdrawal delirium) is a medical emergency and if untreated the mortality rate is around 20%.
  • ➤ The symptoms and signs include disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucination (most commonly visual), coarse tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity.
  • ➤ It usually occurs after 48-72 hours of the last alcohol intake or reduction in the amount of alcohol use.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with facial swelling and decreased urine output. Her parents report that she had a sore throat and fever about two weeks ago. On physical examination, she has periorbital edema and elevated blood pressure. Urinalysis shows cola-colored urine and RBC casts. Laboratory tests reveal low C3 levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is often preceded by a streptococcal infection, such as a sore throat or impetigo. Key features of PSGN include hematuria (cola-colored urine), oliguria, periorbital edema, hypertension, low C3 levels, and RBC casts in the urine.
  • ➤ Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is often preceded by a streptococcal infection, such as a sore throat or impetigo.
  • ➤ Key features of PSGN include hematuria (cola-colored urine), oliguria, periorbital edema, hypertension, low C3 levels, and RBC casts in the urine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of COPD has been admitted for septic shock. Which of the following statements regarding the management of this patient is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Vasopressin is the vasopressor of choice

options.label: B
options.text: Empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics should be initiated within 1 hour of recognition.

options.label: C
options.text: Target a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of at least 65 mmHg.

options.label: D
options.text: Low molecular weight heparin is recommended for prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism.

questions.correct_answer: A. Vasopressin is the vasopressor of choice
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of septic shock, norepinephrine is the first-line vasopressor, not vasopressin. Early administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics, targeting a MAP of at least 65 mmHg, and prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism with low molecular weight heparin are key components of effective treatment.
  • ➤ In the management of septic shock, norepinephrine is the first-line vasopressor, not vasopressin.
  • ➤ Early administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics, targeting a MAP of at least 65 mmHg, and prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism with low molecular weight heparin are key components of effective treatment.

questions.text: Match the following: Monitors (Column A) and their common sites of monitoring (Column B): Column A Invasive blood pressure monitoring Neuromuscular blockade monitoring Central venous cannulation Noninvasive blood pressure monitoring Column B Ulnar nerve Brachial artery Right internal jugular vein Radial artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-a, 3-c, 4-b

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 1-d - Invasive blood pressure monitoring is commonly performed via the radial artery.
  • • 2-a - Neuromuscular blockade monitoring is often assessed at the ulnar nerve.
  • • 3-c Central venous cannulation is typically done via the right internal jugular vein.
  • • 4-b- Non-invasive blood pressure monitoring is most commonly performed using the brachial artery.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Invasive blood pressure is typically monitored through the radial artery, neuromuscular blockade through the ulnar nerve, central venous cannulation via the right internal jugular vein, and non-invasive blood pressure through the brachial artery.
  • ➤ Invasive blood pressure is typically monitored through the radial artery, neuromuscular blockade through the ulnar nerve, central venous cannulation via the right internal jugular vein, and non-invasive blood pressure through the brachial artery.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child from a rural farming community presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and noticeable weight loss over the past few months. His family uses untreated well water and often plays in the surrounding fields. A stool sample is collected and analyzed under microscopy, revealing eggs as shown in the image. Which helminthic infection, commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in the stool as shown in the above image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichuris trichiura infection is diagnosed by the identification of its characteristic eggs in stool samples. The condition can range from asymptomatic to severe, with symptoms including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and potential growth retardation in chronic cases. Treatment involves anti-helminthic medications like mebendazole or albendazole.
  • ➤ Trichuris trichiura infection is diagnosed by the identification of its characteristic eggs in stool samples.
  • ➤ The condition can range from asymptomatic to severe, with symptoms including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and potential growth retardation in chronic cases.
  • ➤ Treatment involves anti-helminthic medications like mebendazole or albendazole.
